stem: For each assessment finding, click to specify if the finding is consistent with right-sided heart failure, left-sided heart failure, or neither.

rationale.correct: Right-sided heart failure leads to systemic fluid retention, causing edema and jugular venous distention. Left-sided heart failure leads to pulmonary congestion, causing crackles and shortness of breath. An S3 heart sound is often associated with left ventricular dysfunction.
rationale.mnemonic: RIGHT: Rest of body fluid retention. LEFT: Lungs fluid retention.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect selections indicate a misunderstanding of the pathophysiology of right-sided and left-sided heart failure and their associated clinical manifestations.
rationale.questionTrap: Students may confuse the symptoms of right-sided and left-sided heart failure. Careful attention to the assessment findings is crucial.
clinicalPearls: Right-sided heart failure: Think systemic congestion.
Left-sided heart failure: Think pulmonary congestion.

itemContext.sbar: John Smith is a 72-year-old male admitted with shortness of breath and edema. He has a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease.
